summary: This is an email chain from December 2008 discussing the GPS monitoring conditions of Jeffrey Epstein's work release program. It clarifies that Epstein would be alerted if he entered an 'exclusionary zone' near a victim's address but would not be told whose address it was. The correspondence is between a U.S. Attorney's Office representative and defense attorneys.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email chain; his GPS monitoring conditions and exclusionary zones related to victims' addresses are being discussed.

persons.name: Robert C. Josefsberg
persons.context: A recipient of the email who asks for clarification about whether Epstein will know the details of the exclusionary zones.

persons.name: Katherine W. Ezell
persons.context: A recipient of the email; she initially contacted the U.S. Attorney's office to inquire about the exclusionary zones.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Listed as a recipient in the initial email from the U.S. Attorney's office regarding the exclusionary zones.

persons.name: Captain Sleeth
persons.context: The law enforcement official from PBSO who informed the U.S. Attorney's office that victim address information for the GPS would remain confidential and not be provided to Epstein.

persons.name: Mr. Goldberger
persons.context: Mentioned as the destination (his office) for Epstein's authorized travel from jail to work.

connections.description: Captain Sleeth, representing the Palm Beach Sheriff's Office, is responsible for managing the GPS exclusionary zones that restrict Epstein's movements.
Josefsberg is corresponding about the specific conditions of Epstein's GPS monitoring, indicating a legal representation role.
Ezell initiated contact with the U.S. Attorney's office to inquire about protections (exclusionary zones) for clients potentially connected to Epstein's case.
Epstein is permitted to travel from jail to Mr. Goldberger's office for work as part of his release conditions.

events.title: Inquiry about GPS Exclusionary Zones
events.description: Katherine W. Ezell contacts the U.S. Attorney's office to ask if Epstein will be told the names or addresses of victims added to his GPS exclusionary zones.

events.title: Clarification of GPS Monitoring Rules
events.description: A U.S. Attorney's office representative explains the technical details of Epstein's GPS monitoring, confirming he would not know specific victim addresses, only that he entered a prohibited zone.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was on a work release program with GPS monitoring that included 'exclusionary zones' around victims' addresses.
The Palm Beach Sheriff's Office (via Captain Sleeth) confirmed that victim addresses added to the GPS system would remain confidential and not be disclosed to Epstein.
Epstein's permitted travel was strictly from jail to work (Mr. Goldberger's office) and back; any deviation could trigger an alarm if he neared an exclusionary zone.
The email chain shows coordination between the U.S. Attorney's office, defense attorneys, and law enforcement regarding the implementation of protective measures for victims.
